item.title: Call of Duty Warzone April 7 Patch Notes—Buy Stations Receive Major Update & Attachments Suddenly Removed
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/call-of-duty-warzone-april-7-patch-notes-buy-stations-receive-major-update-attachments-suddenly-removed/

Raven Software was forced to step in on April 7 with a new Warzone update in Verdansk after two weapon attachments became overpowered and the number of Buy Stations in trios was incorrect.

It’s not unusual for Warzone updates to accidentally introduce new issues, but Season 3 avoided glaring setbacks. Despite some complaints about the HDR being too powerful and not having enough armor plates on the map, players have enjoyed having iconic weapons like the Kilo 141 back in the game.

In addition, Season 3’s weapon balancing changes created a healthy variety of meta weapon options for short or long-range engagements. In saying that, two attachments disrupted that harmony.

Warzone April 7 Patch Notes Explained

Snakeshot Ammunition and Thermal 6x Scope Removed

.500 Snakeshot Ammunition is an attachment for the Basilisk pistol that transforms the weapon into a shotgun in close-range engagements. Over the years, there have been several instances of the attachment becoming too powerful in Warzone, and it happened again in Season 3.

With the ammunition type equipped with the Akimbo attachment, the pistols consistently two-shot killed enemies up close, much faster than every other short-range meta weapon.

This update temporarily restricts the attachment. Meanwhile, the Thermal 6x Scope has also been temporarily removed because the scope didn’t have any glint. This was a massive issue because scope glint helps warn players that an enemy is looking at them.

Buy Station Change

Raven Software reduced the amount of Buy Stations to Trios to better reflect the larger squad sizes. Usually, the map scales the number of available Buy Stations based on the squad size of a lobby because larger teams don’t need as many Buy Stations.

All Warzone April 7 Update Patch Notes

Activision posted the complete patch notes for Warzone’s April 7 update.

Global

  • Recently Disabled Items
    • Snakeshot Ammunition
    • Thermal 6x Scope

Battle Royale

  • Buy Stations
    • We’ve adjusted the number of static buy stations that spawn in Battle Royale Trios to match other squad sizes.

Resurgence, Plunder

  • Recently Enabled Items
    • Bunker Buster

The Warzone devs also assured players that a fix is coming to address the issue that impacts the Hybrid and Slide Only settings and announced that the Endo Titanium Core skin for the T-800 Operator skin will be nerfed to improve visibility.

For more on Call of Duty, check out how to unlock the Thermite Lethal and Monolithic Suppressor, or get up to speed on how Warzone Casual works. What else needs to change to make Verdansk better? Let us know on the Insider Gaming Forums.

item.title: BLAST.tv Austin CS2 Major Invites Revealed After Latest Valve Ranking
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/blast-tv-austin-cs2-major-invites-revealed-after-latest-valve-ranking/

The latest monthly Valve Regional Standings update has arrived, determining which Counter-Strike 2 teams receive an invite to the upcoming BLAST.tv Austin CS2 Major. The rankings released today determine which teams will receive direct invites to either Stage 3 or Stage 2, and which teams will compete in the Major Regional Qualifiers to determine who competes in Stage 1.

After months of work, the teams that have guaranteed a spot in the Major already can also guarantees themselves a cut of the lucrative sticker money.

All CS2 Teams Invited to the BLAST.tv Austin Major

16 teams have been invited directly to the BLAST.tv Austin Major, via earning a high enough placement in their respective regional standings. Eight teams will start in Stage 3, meaning they skip the first two Swiss system stages, and eight will start in Stage 2, meaning they only skip the first Swiss stage.

Here are the teams that have been invited, and the region they are representing.

Stage 3

  • Team Vitality (Europe)
  • Team Spirit (Europe)
  • Natus Vincere (Europe)
  • MOUZ (Europe)
  • Aurora (Europe)
  • G2 Esports (Europe)
  • Team Liquid (Americas)
  • The MongolZ (Asia-Pacific)

Stage 2

  • Falcons (Europe)
  • FaZe (Europe)
  • 3DMAX (Europe)
  • Virtus.pro (Europe)
  • paiN Gaming (Americas)
  • FURIA (Americas)
  • MIBR (Americas)
  • M80 (Americas)

Major Regional Qualifiers (MRQ)

The Major Regional Qualifiers are six qualifier tournaments that will determine the 16 teams that will qualify for Stage 1 of the Major.

Here is the distribution of teams that will qualify for Stage 1 via the MRQs, and the teams that will compete in each region’s MRQ.

  • Six teams from Europe:
    • Astralis, SAW, HEROIC, 500, OG, BetBoom, PARIVISION, ENCE, GamerLegion, BC.Game, BIG, B8, Nemiga, Fnatic, 9 Pandas, Metizport
  • Three from South America:
    • Imperial, Legacy, ODDIK, RED Canids, Fluxo, Sharks, BESTIA, Solid
  • Three from North America:
    • Complexity, NRG, Getting Info, Nouns, Wildcard, BLUEJAYS, Marsborne, MIGHT
  • Two from China:
    • Rare Atom, Lynn Vision, TYLOO, DogEvil
  • One from Oceania:
    • SemperFi, ex-Talon, FlyQuest, Rooster
  • One from Asia:
    • The Huns, ATOX, Chinggis Warriors, Eruptions

It’s worth noting that this list of teams receiving BLAST Austin CS2 Major invites are based solely on the rankings released today, and that the official invites are subject to change. The Major Regional Qualifiers will begin in less than two weeks, running from April 14th to 17th.
